Noetherian Space and Dimension

Posted on August 31, 2022 by PL Lee

Zariaki Topology of Rings

Definition 1 (Noetherian Space). A topological space is called Noetherian iff every desending chain of closed sets \[L_1\supseteq L_2\supseteq\cdots\] will eventually stablize. That is, there is some \(n\) s.t. \[L_n=L_{n+1}=\cdots\]

Theorem 1. If a topological space \(X\) is both Noetherian and Hausdorff, it must be finite and descrete.

Proof. Fix \(p\in X\), pick a point other than \(p\), say \(q_1\in X\), and let \(V_1\) and \(W_1\) be distinct open sets containing \(p\) and \(q_1\) respectively. Then we see that \(p\in(X\backslash W_1)=L_1\). If \(p\) is the only element of \(L_1\), it must also be the only point of \(V_1\). Otherwise, pick another \(q_2\in L_1\), and let \(V_2\) and \(W_2\) likewise. Then \(p\in(L_1\backslash W_2)=L_2\), and \(p\in V_1\bigcap V_2\subseteq L_2\). Likewise, if this operation eventually stops at step \(t\), we will know that \(p\) is the only point of the open set \(V_1\bigcap V_2\bigcap\cdots\bigcap V_t\). Otherwise, repeating this operation and we will get a decending chain \[L_1\supseteq L_2\supseteq\cdots\] Since \(X\) is Noetherian, the chain must stablize, which implies there must be some \(L_n=L_{n+1}\), which is impossible due to the selection of \(q_{n+1}\). Thus we know, every point of space \(X\) is open, hence \(X\) is descrete. Apply the property of Noetherian again it’ll be revealed that \(X\) is finite. ◻

Definition 2 (Spectrum of a ring). For a certain ring \(R\), the spectrum \(\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\) is the set of prime ideals of \(R\).

Fixe a ring \(R\), there is an antitone Galois connection between the set of ideals of \(R\) and the subsets of \(\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\). To see this, let \[V(T) = \{p\in\mathfrak{Spec}(R)|T\subset p\}\] and \[Z(S) = \bigcap_{p\in S}p\] in which \(V\) maps an ideal to a subset of \(\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\), and \(Z\) reversely. Under these conventions, the closure operation \[T\mapsto Z(V(T))\] maps an ideal to it’s radical.

Lemma 1. For any ring \(R\), there is a minimal prime ideal \(p\in\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\).

Proof. ◻

Proof. ◻

The spectrum of a ring \(R\) can be made into a topological space, in the sence that a subset \(S\subseteq\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\) is closed if and only if there is a \(T\subseteq R\) such that \(S=Z(T)\). In this sence, the closure of a subset \(S\subseteq\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\) is \(V(Z(R))\), identical to closure in the sence of Galois connection mentioned above. This is called the Zariski topology. Let \[D(f) = \{p\in\mathfrak{Spec}(R)|f\not\in p\}\] Since \(D(f)=\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\backslash V(\{f\})\) we know that \(D\) maps \(R\) to open subsets of \(\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\). For any closed set \(V(T)\), in which \(T\) is nonempty, let \(f\in T\), then we have \(D(f)\bigcap V(T)=\varnothing\), which implies \(\{D(f)|f\in R\}\) is a base of topological space \(\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\).

Definition 3. Let \(X\) be a topological space.

  • We say \(X\) is irreducible if and only if \(X\) is nonempty, and cannot be written into \(X=T_1\bigcup T_2\), where \(T_i\) are closed in \(X\).

  • We say \(Z\subset X\) is an irreducible component of \(X\) if \(Z\) is a maximal irreducible subset of \(X\).

Morphism and Localization

Let \(\varphi\) be a homomorphism from ring \(R\) to ring \(R'\), then there is a natural homoemorphism \[\mathfrak{Spec}(\varphi):\mathfrak{Spec}(R')\rightarrow\mathfrak{Spec}(R)\] Where In other words, \(\mathfrak{Spec}(\cdot)\) is a contravariant functor from category of rings to category of topological spaces.
